Name: Deductive Reasoning - PE
Text: First, Part 1 outlines the strict rules. The process must follow a specific sequence: Application Received → Credit Check → Risk Assessment → Loan Decision → Inform Applicant → [Finalize Documentation if approved] → Close Case. The key constraints are the order of activities and certain conditional steps based on approval or rejection.

Name: Deductive Reasoning - PE
Text: Violations include skipping steps, changing order, finalizing after rejection, or closing without following the logic.

Name: Pattern Recognition - PE
Text: Now looking at the event log: Case 1: Activities in order: Application Received, Credit Check, Risk Assessment, Loan Approved, Inform Applicant, Finalize Documentation, Close Case. All steps in order. Approved so they finalized docs before closing. No issues here. So no normative violations.

Name: Validation - PE
Text: Desiderata? Let's check timestamps. Credit Check was 30 minutes after application (within 24h). Inform Applicant was 2 hours after decision (within 48h). No Follow-up Call mentioned for Case 1? Wait, in the log for Case 3 it's noted that there's no Follow-up Call.

Name: Deductive Reasoning - IND
Text: The desiderata says Follow-up Call is encouraged but not required. So missing it is a desideratum violation.

Name: Pattern Recognition - NE
Text: Case 2: Activities: Application Received → Risk Assessment (without prior Credit Check) → Credit Check → Loan Rejected → Finalize Documentation → Close Case.

Name: Deductive Reasoning - NE
Text: First activity after Application Received is Risk Assessment without Credit Check first—this violates ordering rule that Credit Check must come before Risk Assessment.

Name: Deductive Reasoning - NE
Text: Additionally, after Loan Rejected they performed Finalize Documentation which is prohibited; then closed the case.

Name: Deductive Reasoning - NE
Text: Loan Decision (Rejected) at Jan11th 09:30; next activity is Finalize Documentation at 10:00—but wait where is 'Inform Applicant'? According to normative rules, after Loan Decision must come Inform Applicant regardless of approval or rejection.

Name: Hypothesis Generation - IND
Text: For Case 2, perhaps operational delays or human error could justify some of these missteps, like performing Risk Assessment first out of rushed prioritization or unfamiliarity with the strict rules.

Name: Pattern Recognition - IND
Text: Case 3: Activities: Application Received → Credit Check (after two days) → Risk Assessment → Loan Approved → Inform Applicant (two days later) → Finalize Documentation → Close Case.

Name: Deductive Reasoning - PE
Text: Sequence order here follows Application Received → Credit Check → Risk Assessment → Loan Decision → Inform → Finalize → Close, which aligns with the approved path.

Name: Validation - IND
Text: However, Credit Check happened more than 24 hours after application received (Jan 12th application received; Credit Check Jan 14th)—violates timing recommendation.

Name: Validation - IND
Text: Inform Applicant was two days later (Jan 14th decision vs. inform on Jan 16th)—slightly exceeding recommended 48 hours.

Name: Pattern Recognition - IND
Text: Other than timing delays, no steps were skipped or reversed in Case 3's sequence.

Name: Hypothesis Generation - IND
Text: For Case 3 delays, perhaps weekends or high workloads caused the delays, or they were waiting on third-party information.

Name: Deductive Reasoning - IND
Text: All three cases missed Follow-up Calls, which is a desideratum violation but does not break strict rules.
